original_data.question: A 3-year-old male is brought in to his pediatrician by his mother because she is concerned that he is not growing appropriately. Physical examination is notable for frontal bossing and shortened upper and lower extremities. His axial skeleton appears normal. He is at the 7th percentile for height and 95th percentile for head circumference. He demonstrates normal intelligence and is able to speak in three-word sentences. He first sat up without support at twelve months and started walking at 24 months. Genetic analysis reveals an activating mutation in a growth factor receptor. Which of the following physiologic processes is most likely disrupted in this patient’s condition?

model_response:
This patient’s condition is consistent with a diagnosis of achondroplasia, which is caused by activating mutations in the FGFR3 gene. FGFR3 is a negative regulator of endochondral ossification, which is the process by which most of the skeleton is formed. In this process, mesenchymal cells differentiate into chondrocytes, which produce a cartilaginous template that is replaced by bone during development. Intramembranous ossification, which is the direct conversion of mesenchymal cells into osteoblasts, is not disrupted in this condition. Osteoblast maturation, which is the process by which osteoblasts differentiate from mesenchymal cells, is not disrupted in this condition. Type I collagen production, which is the major component of bone and cailage, is not disrupted in this condition.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.
Female parents, human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A skeletal deformity characterized by an unusually prominent forehead. Causes include acromegaly, Hurler syndrome, Silver-Russell syndrome, and thalassemia major.
In a place or position that is higher.
The region of the lower limb in animals, extending from the gluteal region to the FOOT, and including the BUTTOCKS; HIP; and LEG.
Situated on or along or in the direction of an axis.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
A circumferential measurement of the head at the widest point, which is traditionally above the eyebrows.
The ability to learn and to deal with new situations and to deal effectively with tasks involving abstractions.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
An activity in which the body advances at a slow to moderate pace by moving the feet in a coordinated fashion. This includes recreational walking, walking for fitness, and competitive race-walking.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
To cause something to start or to stimulate activity.
Any detectable and heritable change in the genetic material that causes a change in the GENOTYPE and which is transmitted to daughter cells and to succeeding generations.
Cell surface receptors that bind growth or trophic factors with high affinity, triggering intracellular responses which influence the growth, differentiation, or survival of cells.
A biologic function, activity, or process involving either specialized organ functions, individual organs, organ systems, body parts, or whole organisms.
A response indicating that an individual is or was not at all disrupted.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
